data.title: The Anime Madhouse
data.meta_description: Posts about santa written by fiddletwix
data.text:
Plot: Prep and Landing is a special covert team of elves who go out every Christmas Eve night to prepare the homes of children all across the globe for Santaâ€™s arrival. Their services are vital to ensuring that Santa can land, deliver gifts without being seen and leave without being caught. Wayne is a legendary member of Prep and Landing, but heâ€™s burned out and ready to leave those days behind him for a cushy life in a higher position. When that doesnâ€™t work out, he becomes lackadaisical and uncaring about his job, which leads to a major catastrophe that puts the Christmas spirit of an innocent child on the line.

Breakdown: This is an interesting one for me, because I know for a fact that I heard of this special when it first came out, and it seems kinda familiar, but for the life of me I donâ€™t remember sitting down and watching it. Shame if I didnâ€™t, because this is an excellent Christmas special.

Someone said this seemed very reminiscent of Arthur Christmas, and I agree, to an extent. While it doesnâ€™t have the Aardman style to the artwork, the way Santa and the elves are portrayed comes off a lot like the way they were portrayed in Arthur Christmas, only not in a negative slant. In Arthur Christmas, they were getting so reliant on technology that it really seemed like Santa didnâ€™t need to go out to visit houses every year, the elves were being phased out or just made to be tech specialists, and the spirit of Christmas was dying as the use of technology was increasing.

However, this special portrays the integration of technology in a much more positive light. Santaâ€™s still Santa, and the elves are still the elves, but they have new jobs to ensure that Christmas magic stays alive and well. For example, while they treat the launching of Santaâ€™s sleigh almost as if itâ€™s a rocket launch, they toy with the process to not diminish the original roles of Santaâ€™s reindeer and sleigh. When they say to â€œRev up the enginesâ€ they send down an elf who basically acts as the hype man for the reindeer who gets them super excited before they head out.

Itâ€™s a much more natural and fun integration than they had in Arthur Christmas, but, then again, that was the point in that movie. The technology here is more of a fun backdrop for the antics of the story, not a focal part of the story.

I really like how Prep and Landing is made out to be such an integral part of the process. Itâ€™s a pretty unique idea to have elves who prepare the house before Santa visits to help ensure everything goes smoothly. Itâ€™s pretty realistic, too â€“ at least in regards to the Santa mythos. An operation like Santaâ€™s would want to make their activities as efficient and covert as humanly possible, and having a special team of elves preparing the house beforehand while also doing everything in their power to streamline everything back at the North Pole makes it much easier to pull off this job every year.

In regards to the story, I feel like this plot lends itself more to adults than children, and not because itâ€™s mature or anything, but the themes surrounding it give me a feeling like if I watched it and enjoyed it as a child Iâ€™d have more of an appreciation for it as an adult.

Wayne starts out the special being arrogant and uncaring. We donâ€™t really spend a lot of time with him as a young and enthusiastic Prep and Landing agent. Once we learn of his backstory, we see him as a cocky guy who thinks heâ€™s about to land (hehe) a fancy promotion to being head of the naughty list. While he is being arrogant and kinda rude, heâ€™s not being so bad that heâ€™s obnoxious or your donâ€™t sympathize with him.

As we learn later, heâ€™s just a very, very burned out elf who, despite being top of his game in Prep and Landing, wants to go higher and get more respect. That position is ripped from him for no given reason, and the promotion is handed to his partner â€“ an elf he trained. We never learn much about his partner nor do we ever see him after the backstory portion. Him getting the job doesnâ€™t matter as much as Wayne not getting it.

Being burned out, wanting more out of your job and losing promotions to younger people who may or may not have snaked them from you are all very real situations adults find themselves in more and more. Not to mention that the office-esque vibe the entire factory gives off (while still being loaded with Christmas stuff, of course) makes it feel, almost sadly, very familiar to adults. Theyâ€™re not really aspects of the story that kids get â€“ and they donâ€™t really have to connect with that aspect of the story. They really just need to know that Wayne is a grump who is fed up with doing the same stuff over and over, and he needs to rediscover his Christmas spirit to get back in the swing of things.

Wayne does get dangerously close to being obnoxious when they enter their first house. Wayne is so done with his job after losing his promotion that he leaves every task in the home up to the brand-new rookie, Lanny, who, despite being enthusiastic and skilled, is still extremely inexperienced and self-conscious. He idolizes Wayne since heâ€™s such a legend in Prep and Landing, but Wayne just dumps all of the work on him while he goes to laze around and take advantage of the comforts of the home.

Lanny does his best, but he still screws up some stuff because heâ€™s never done this before. Wayne wonâ€™t help him because he doesnâ€™t take his job seriously anymore.

This, of course, leads to them getting caught by the kid in the house. Heâ€™s a nice young lad who immediately starts taking pictures of them, because, well duh. Most kids, especially after the advent of digital cameras and smartphones, would immediately jump on taking pictures of elves in the house. Though Lanny was smart enough to delete the pictures when they managed to knock the kid out.

Wayne still doesnâ€™t care all that much about causing this mess until he realizes that they still havenâ€™t prepared the landing strip on the roof, and thereâ€™s a big snowstorm coming through. Santa is unable to land safely, so theyâ€™re forced to do something they almost never do â€“ call off a visit to a house.

Only then, when he completely screws up Christmas for an innocent boy, does he both see how badly heâ€™s messed up and how important their job truly is. They save Christmas for the boy together, and Wayne isnâ€™t hailed as a hero or anything (which he shouldnâ€™t) but heâ€™s offered a promotion to director of the nice list, and he turns it down because his true place is with Prep and Landing.

All the way through, this special was very entertaining. It wasnâ€™t the most emotional thing it the world, but itâ€™s not trying to be, and I think it could have stood being a little longer, but it was funny, well-animated, a little heartwarming and managed to create fairly memorable, likable and relatable characters in a short 22 minute time frame. Itâ€™s a special I really feel would instantly become a classic for families. Iâ€™m certainly thinking about putting it on my annual watch list for the holiday season.

It received an Emmy for Outstanding Animated Program (for Programming Less than One Hour), it was nominated for nine Annie awards â€“ winning three â€“ and it was so popular that it actually dethroned the Rankin-Bass Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer special as the number one Christmas special on TV.

Prep and Landing went on to have a sequel called Prep and Landing: Naughty vs. Nice, which I may get around to watching and reviewing this month, several shorter spin-offs and even a comic book crossover where Wayne and Lanny prepare the Avengers mansion for Christmas. However, nowadays, Prep and Landing is all but dead, and it seems the sequel is kinda the reason for that. There was a third Prep and Landing special meant to come out some time after 2011, but the plans were scrapped because reception for the second special was too disappointing.

Still, Prep and Landing and Naughty vs. Nice air every year to this day (although, for some reason, they stopped in 2020, theyâ€™re set to return to Freeform, ABC and the Disney Channel this year.) and it seems to be a well-remembered short for many people. I certainly enjoyed myself, and I recommend anyone reading to give it a shot. Itâ€™s available on Disney+, but will also be airing on Disney Channel, Freeform and ABC throughout the month.

If my work makes you feel jolly and youâ€™d like to send some Christmas cheer my way, please consider leaving a gift under my Ko-Fi tree. Every donation goes to helping me pay my bills and keeping this blog running like Santaâ€™s Workshop. Thank you! Merry Christmas, Happy Holidays and have a Wonderful New Year! ğŸ„â˜ƒï¸

CotD(s): None, unless you count Santa andâ€¦is it really necessary to talk about him?

Pre-Analysis Notes: Hah! Gotcha! You thought I had reviewed all of the Christmas specials for Pokemon? Nope! Thereâ€™s still one, technically two-ish more, but thereâ€™s a reason why I havenâ€™t reviewed them yet.

You guys remember how I talked about the Pokemon Shock incident and how it screwed up the episode order? Well, Holiday Hi-Jynx, their first foray into Christmas, and Snow Way Out were both booted from the planned lineup entirely, which is the main reason why they were subsequently thrown off my analysis lineup for the moment as well since Iâ€™m strictly going in numerical order as listed on Bulbapedia. Technically, these episodes have no official numbers. They were originally set to air right around Christmastime in 1997, but since the producers didnâ€™t want to air a Christmas special and a winter-themed episode in April/May, they opted to air the two episodes as specials much later.

I donâ€™t why they bothered, really, because they ended up actually releasing both of the episodes on October 5, 1998. Yeah, airing Christmas/winter themed episodes is so much more fitting in the dead of fall, a month before Halloween. Good job.

At least the US had their ducks in a more uniform row, because they aired the dub on December 11, 1999. (Snow Way Out airing a week later on December 18th.)

Despite this being a more fitting airing spot, this did cause some major confusion. Back when I was a kid, these episodes premiered with no fanfare or explanation of what happened. And the reason this was necessary was because, out of nowhere, Ashâ€™s troublesome Charizard was back to being a lovable Charmander, and Misty no longer had Togepi yet still had her Starmie and Horsea, which she had left at the Cerulean Gym at that point. I chalked it up to being an old episode I mustâ€™ve missed, but it still nagged me, especially considering that, at the time of this airing in the States, Ash was prepping for the Indigo League tournament.

The trouble doesnâ€™t end there.

Say hello to Jynx! She is the reason this episode is kinda, sorta, somewhat, ehhh maybe, but not really, depending on how you look at it, banned.

Jynx was heavily criticized as being a racist depiction of a black woman shortly after this episode aired in the US. As a result, the episode was taken out of rotation after a handful of airings and has never reappeared in syndication.

Unlike most banned episodes, however, you can still find this episode fairly easily. Itâ€™s on the VHS and the original volume 3 of the Indigo League DVD set, itâ€™s on Cartoon Network Video and Cartoon Networkâ€™s On Demand service, itâ€™s available on Boomerang and you can find it on the Japanese versions of Amazon Prime Video, Netflix and Hulu.

Subsequent airings have been edited to change Jynxâ€™s skin color to purple to avoid controversy (Kinda like how Mr. Popoâ€™s skin was changed to bright Genie-from-Aladdin blue during his appearances in DBZKai.) but several sources and countries show the original version.

Despite this, the episode is still quietly banned in certain regions. Itâ€™s not listed on Pokemon.com, itâ€™s not available on Netflix, it wasnâ€™t included in the re-release of volume 3 of the Indigo League DVD set, and itâ€™s not included in the Indigo League complete collection DVD set. Additionally, the episode is fully banned in South Korea, and India only aired it once before taking it out of rotation entirely.

The edited version has not been applied to the English dub, so that makes up for a decent amount of the trouble in obtaining this episode.

This initial backlash caused a ripple effect. While Jynx is not a forbidden Pokemon in the anime like Porygon basically is, 4Kids opted to skip over another episode â€“ Ep250: The Ice Cave â€“ because Jynx was so prevalent in it to the point where removing her scenes would destroy the footage and reduce the runtime too much. Episode 287 â€“ All Things Bright and Beautifly â€“ was also edited in the English dub to remove a sequence with Jynx.

Even the Gen II games and the manga were retroactively edited in the west to change Jynxâ€™s skin to purple. Eventually, Game Freak would choose to officially change the characterâ€™s skin color to purple to allow it to be featured in the anime and games without additional edits in other areas.

As for why Jynx was designed this way, well, I canâ€™t bring myself to say outright that the designers gunned for a clear black woman stereotype for the sake of being bigots. I donâ€™t like slinging accusations of that caliber around so flippantly without firm evidence. However, itâ€™s hard not to see it.

Thereâ€™s a theory that she is based on ganguro style, which was popular in the 90s. Ganguro involves dying your hair blond, heavy tanning and wearing a lot of makeup. The actual style, while being rather gaudy, shows the personâ€™s skin as being very orange. You might remember Jessie and James sported ganguro style during the first part of the St. Anne arc.

With that in mind, itâ€™s hard to say that it was taking inspiration from that. By logic, Jynxâ€™s skin would be orange or burnt orange, not black.

Howeverâ€¦.

There are even more extreme versions of ganguro â€“ Yamanba and Manba, where the tanning is much darker (being dark brown, not orange) and the makeup, accessories and hairstyles are even more outlandish. However, considering this gained popularity long after this episode was created, around 2004, I doubt either of these were the inspiration.

Plus, itâ€™s really hard to seek justification in something where the name, ganguro, can literally translate to â€˜black faceâ€™â€¦â€¦â€¦

Iâ€™m having trouble getting that anyway because what relation would ganguro have with either psychic powers or ice? Youâ€™d think with the requirement of getting so much tanning you might as well jettison yourself into the sun that such a thing couldnâ€™t be further from ice.

Despite having no connection to Santa in the games, itâ€™s also been theorized that, considering Jynxâ€™s role as Santaâ€™s helper in this episode, it might be based on Zwarte Piet or Black Pete, who is a companion of Santa in Dutch folkloreâ€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦andâ€¦..itâ€™s still racist because, even though the character himself is black, most portrayals of him are done by white people in blackfaceâ€¦

Also, I doubt that theory too because Jynx is clearly designed as a female.

Finally, thereâ€™s the theory that it was based on Hel, the Nordic goddess of the underworld who ruled Niflheim, a land of ice and snow. This theory seems to have the best logic to it, but Helâ€™s face is either meant to be half-blue and half-flesh colored or half-black and half-flesh colored; not fully black. So either they screwed up the facial design or this theory is wrong too.

I never much cared for Jynx either way. I find her to be very creepy on all fronts (Creepy design, creepy voice, creepy movement, creepy blushing, creepy kissing attack â€“ creepycreepycreepy) but I think itâ€™s a good thing that she was changed to purple over the years.

Even if her entire existence is a big question mark in regards to intentions, thereâ€™s really no getting around the implications, especially considering only one of the three viable theories I read didnâ€™t include mentions of flatout blackface (Itâ€™s also theorized that Jynx are based on opera singers, given their overweight appearance and musical ability, but this confuses me just as much as the others, quite frankly.) Changing her to purple was a much better course of action than trying to justify her offensive appearance â€“ if they even have a justification.

Keep in mind, everything I just discussed were fan theories on her origins â€“ people coming up with less offensive possibilities for Jynxâ€™s existence. I donâ€™t think an official explanation was ever given, which is fairly suspect. Even if it is meant to be a racist depiction of a black woman, which is, of course, insanely messed up, what does that have to do with ice or psychic powers? What were they going for? I just donâ€™t understand Jynx at all.

I donâ€™t really want to press this matter into even worse implications, but I canâ€™t help but ask this question. If people find that Santaâ€™s elves are basically slavesâ€¦and taking Jynx as being a depiction of a stereotypical black womanâ€¦..Does that mean Iâ€™m technically watching a Christmas special with depictions of black people as Santaâ€™s slaves? I really wish I had turned my brain off before it went down that route, because if you lock onto that idea, this episode just gets so much worse. Itâ€™s bad enough that Jynx technically are indeed â€˜ownedâ€™ by their Trainers in the first placeâ€¦â€¦

To be honest, other than having ice powers and being human-like, I donâ€™t know why Jynx was the Pokemon chosen to be stand-ins for Santaâ€™s elves to begin with. I know Delibird doesnâ€™t exist yet, but certainly thereâ€™s a better option.

Mâ€¦merryâ€¦Christmasâ€¦..Iâ€™m really uncomfortable now.

Plot: On Christmas Eve, Team Rocket plans on trapping Santa and taking all of the presents for themselves. Jessie has a vendetta against Santa, believing him to be a thief who stole her doll when he visited on Christmas ten years agoâ€¦.Only â€˜heâ€™ was actually a Jynx working for Santa that she believes was actually Santa.

Meanwhile, Ash tries to capture what he thinks is a wild Jynx waiting on a beach. After a failed attempt, they surmise that it has a Trainer after seeing it holding a boot belonging to none other than Santa Claus! Jynx psychically transmits her story to Ash and the others â€“ some time ago, she was shining Santaâ€™s boot when the ice she was standing on broke away. She drifted to shore and is now desperate to reach Santa.

Ash, Misty and Brock agree to help her out, worried that Santa wonâ€™t be able to deliver gifts without his Jynx or his other boot. They grab a raft and head off in the direction of the North Pole, using their Water Pokemon to help pull them along. After a long, long while and exhausting their Pokemon, Ash finds one of Santaâ€™s telepathic Lapras who has been following them for a while. Realizing their intentions are good, it decides to pull them along for the rest of the ride.

When they arrive, however, Team Rocket springs up. They trap Ash and the others in a net and capture Jynx, whom Jessie still mistakenly believes is Santa. They then head to the workshop to steal all of the toys. Jessie spots the real Santa and they hold him hostage so all of the Jynx will hand over the presents. Ash and the others try to intervene, but hold themselves back to protect Santa.

Jessie chats with Santa who asks why sheâ€™s doing this. After explaining her story, Jynx perks up and runs off to retrieve Jessieâ€™s doll â€“ now fixed. Santa explains that his Jynx had gone to deliver presents to her and noticed her broken dolly on the floor. She took it to get fixed, but they couldnâ€™t return it since Jessie no longer believed in him and heâ€™s not allowed to tread in the homes of hearts that donâ€™t believe in him.

While she tearfully reunited with her doll, Jessie continues her plan anyway. However, theyâ€™re all stopped by Lapras, who freezes their sub with Ice Beam. Ash uses Charmander to free them all from the ropes and commands him to use Fire Spin on the sub. The ice melts and Team Rocket escapes.

Santa commands his legion of Jynx to use Psywave to pick up their sub, shake out all of the presents, destroy the sub and blast off Team Rocket.

With Santa and the presents safe, Santa heads off on his sleigh to bring Christmas to people all over the world. Jynx and Lapras deliver presents to Ash, Misty, Brock and Pikachu, bringing them all Christmas cheer.

Meanwhile, a beaten up Team Rocket lies in bed, waiting for Santa to hopefully deliver gifts to them despite their actions. He does show up, but all that happens is Jynx uses Lovely Kiss on them all to make them sleep. It may not be the best Christmas for them, but they certainly didnâ€™t do anything to get on the nice list this year.

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€“

â€“ Whose castle is Team Rocket staying in?

â€“ I kinda understand why Jessieâ€™s doing the title card read today, but itâ€™s also a little weird.

â€“ Jessie has a really nice house for a kid who supposedly grew up so poor that her mother fed her snowâ€¦.

â€“ If Santa sends out his Jynx to deliver presentsâ€¦.whatâ€¦exactlyâ€¦does HE do?

â€“ Why is Ash so gung-ho about catching a Jynx?

â€“ I love how Misty and Ash are claiming itâ€™s very weird to leave a Pokemon alone outside, but theyâ€™ve left Pokemon in the middle of a street sitting in a kiddie pool beforeâ€¦.

â€“ Why is Jynx blushing when it looks at the boot? Is she in love with him?

â€“ If Jynx could transmit messages telepathically, why did she even need to waste time with the boot?

â€“ Couldnâ€™t Jynx have just used Ice Beam to create a bridge to get back to shore?

â€“ Is Brock seriously asking how Santaâ€™s going to deliver presents without his Jynx? You donâ€™t even know what she does as Santaâ€™s Pokemon.

â€“ Look, Iâ€™m trying to give this episode some modicum of leeway in the logic department, because itâ€™s a kidâ€™s show trying to talk about Santa, but Ash and the others are really planning to head to the North Pole on a wooden raft they either found or somehow made in about ten seconds. Unless the North Pole is much closer to Kanto in the Pokemon world than it is in our world, theyâ€™re either going to die, their Pokemon are going to die from exhaustion, both or theyâ€™ll all be lost adrift at sea for a long, long time.

â€“ Huh, Mistyâ€™s actually being accommodating to Psyduck. Itâ€™s a Christmas miracle.

â€“ Hey, the Gyarados sub! Yay!

â€“ I sincerely doubt Ash has the strength to pull that raft at any reasonable speed. Also, did none of them think to just bring oars?

â€“ So a non-Psychic Lapras can telepathically speak, but Psychic Jynx can only project images and only through touchâ€¦â€¦â€¦.Kay.

Also, why is Lapras glowing so brightly when it first meets Ash?

â€“ I feel I should call BS on Misty not knowing what a Lapras is, but Iâ€™ll refrain from making a â€˜Why Use the Pokedex?â€™ note since I have no way of knowing if she does. Would be weird of someone who is currently trying to be a Water Pokemon Master is all.

â€“ Lapras has been watching them for â€˜some timeâ€™ but didnâ€™t think to offer them a ride or a tow? Jerk.

â€“ Okay, so Laprasâ€™ logic with not appearing sooner was not knowing their intentionsâ€¦.but she can speak telepathically, which means she must be able to read minds and thus easily know their intentions immediately. Or it couldâ€™ve just asked the Jynx telepathically if she trusted these kids. Also, Lapras, itâ€™s a bunch of kids on a wooden raft in the middle of the ocean trying to get to the North Pole to deliver Santaâ€™s Jynx back to him. You canâ€™t get much more wholesome that that. Youâ€™re just a jerk, Lapras â€“ which sucks because I adore Lapras.

â€“ Itâ€™s really nice and cool of Jynx to use her hair as an umbrella for Mistyâ€¦â€¦.That sure is a unique sentence.

â€“ I just realized that they were heading to the North Pole without any winter clothesâ€¦.now that I think about it, in the next episode they head into snowy mountains without winter clothes. Delia constantly asks Ash if he has clean underwear on but never thinks to ask if he has weather-appropriate attire for his journeys?

â€“ Santa Claus lives on a spiky ice island of death?â€¦â€¦COOL!

â€“ Hah, I like how the motto music sped up when Jessie and James realized how cold it was.

â€“ Neither Jynx nor Lapras did anything to the missile or net when it was being so slowly deployed.

â€“ How does Santa not have a second pair of boots? Also, Jynx has been gone for some time, supposedly, so how has Santa not made or otherwise obtained another pair in the meantime? Has he been walking around outside with one shoe?

â€“ This version of Santaâ€™s pretty lame. Not only does he have a bunch of Jynx do most of his work, but he also apparently is not all-seeing because he doesnâ€™t realize Jessie and James are bad guys and probably naughty list recipients.

â€“ What is up with how fast Meowthâ€™s lips are moving when heâ€™s telling the Jynx to load up the gifts? Thatâ€™s not typical Japanese to English lip flap syncing trouble, thatâ€™s almost like they sped up the footage.

â€“ Iâ€™m realizing now that, even accepting the silliness of Jessie believing a Jynx is Santa, why is she still insisting SantaJynx is male? She keeps using male pronouns, but not only is Jynx clearly female-based, but her species is 100% female.

â€“ Iâ€™m surprised Jessie was so emotionally impacted by Jynx stealing her dollâ€¦the one she broke in a fit of unjustified rage and didnâ€™t react much when it happened.

â€“ Okay, wait, wait, time out. Jessie broke her doll, Jynx came to deliver presentsâ€¦.didnâ€™t do that, grabbed her doll off the floor and took it, ran off to get it fixed, but couldnâ€™t return it for ten years because Jessie didnâ€™t believe in Santa anymore after that?

First of all;

Santa: â€œThere, you see? I knew my Jynx would never steal anything.â€ She took someoneâ€™s property from their house and didnâ€™t return it. Thatâ€™s stealing.

Second of all;

Santa: â€œI repaired it in my sleighâ€¦.â€ Wait, that means you repaired it right then and thereâ€¦.Why wouldnâ€™t you just instantly give it back then?

Third;

Santa: â€œWe tried to go back, but you didnâ€™t believe in me anymore, and Iâ€™m powerless to go where hearts are closed.â€ Powerless to go where hearts are closedâ€¦.thatâ€™s a new one. And a stupid one.

If you repaired it in the sleigh, that means Jessie instantly stopped believing in you when Jynx went up the chimney. Thatâ€™s a bit extreme.

She never stopped believing in Santa Claus anyway. If she did, she wouldnâ€™t be in the North Pole right now. She just mistakenly believed Jynx was Santa.

Does this mean Santa canâ€™t enter most houses? Because most parents donâ€™t believe in Santa, and many older kids donâ€™t either. If he canâ€™t enter the home of non-believers entirely, his trip must be much shorter than we think.

Even if all of that was true, why take the doll with you? Why not put it on her windowsill or, oh I dunno, send your non-Santa-and-thus-not-restricted-by-the-belief-thing back down the chimney to return what she stole?

â€“ Oh my God, Ash, why would you have Charmander burn the ropes and give you all third degree burns when you could have just had him untie you? Come to think of it, you must have a decent amount of movement capability if you could find, grab and send out Charmanderâ€™s Pokeballâ€¦.

â€“ Yes, Charmander, Fire Spin the thing that currently holds all of the presents for all of the little girls and boys of the world. I hope they asked Santa for asbestosâ€¦.

â€“ I get that Team Rocketâ€™s Pokemon are perfectly fine following the orders of either Jessie or James, but why does Jessie have Weezingâ€™s Pokeball?

â€“ Also, Team Rocket has a point â€“ Ash just helped by thawing them out after Lapras froze them. Why would he even consider doing that?

â€“ If these Jynx all know Psywave, then theyâ€™ve all been given the TM to learn it. Iâ€™d think another good TM to give them would be Teleport so it would make deliveries essentially instantaneous. You wouldnâ€™t even need the sleigh, and none of your Jynx would ever get lost.

â€“ I should question the flying Rapidash, but I moreso want to comment on Santa saying â€˜No reindeer.â€™ Oh, Santa, just wait a gen.

â€“ That snow effect is one of the worst Iâ€™ve ever seen. It doesnâ€™t even look like snow. It looks like fully white ladybugs crawling on the screen in four intersecting lines. I make better snow animations than that, and thatâ€™s just sad.

â€“ Aw itâ€™s nice that they got presents. I hope itâ€™s winter clothes because some of you have to be losing some appendages at this point.

â€“ Pikachu getting a gift is really cute and nice, but I really hope Santa has gifts for all of their Pokemon, otherwise this little note is actually quite unfair and more blatant favoritism â€“ and this time itâ€™s not even from Ash!

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

Iâ€™ve always remembered this episode as being really weird, really confusing and just strange, but I guess itâ€™s not a particularly terrible Christmas special. There are so many other better holiday Pokemon specials out there that I certainly wouldnâ€™t place this at the top tier of your Christmas must-watch list, but itâ€™s alright.

Amid all of the controversy and other messes this episode was wrapped up in, youâ€™d hope this episode would be one worth waiting for, but itâ€™s really not. I still think itâ€™s really weird, really confusing and just strange. There are so many questionable writing choices made in this episode, both Japanese and English, that itâ€™s actually somewhat impressive what a massive tangle of nonsensical weird they made out of a Christmas special.

Jynxâ€™s mere existence may be enough to put some people off of this episode, especially if your brain runs a little wild with the implications like mine did. I really hope Iâ€™m just reading too far into things again. Otherwise, itâ€™s an okay-ish watch around the holidays. Nearly any other entry in the â€˜Pikachuâ€™s Winter Vacationâ€™ series would be a better alternative, though.

If my work makes you feel jolly and youâ€™d like to send some Christmas cheer my way, please consider leaving a gift under my Ko-Fi tree. Every donation goes to helping me pay my bills and keeping this blog running as well as Santaâ€™s Workshop. Thank you! Merry Christmas, Happy Holidays and have a Wonderful New Year! â™¥

Plot: Rudolph the Redâ€”Weâ€™ve been over this.

Breakdown: Hi 1998!

1998: â€œErrâ€¦hi.â€

I was nine in 1998!

1998: â€œCongratulations.â€

Hey 1998, Iâ€™m gonna do you a favor!

1998: â€œWhat?â€

Iâ€™m gonna make Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer into a movie!

1998: â€œUhhh, isnâ€™t that already a thing?â€

Yeah, but that was made in 1964. People who were kids in that year are old people now. We need to jazz things up a bit for the 90s. Say, did your precious 60s version have the northern lights depicted as fairies in silk robes?

1998: â€œâ€¦..Noooooooooo.â€

Did it have an ice queen named Stormella?

1998: â€œAlright, that nameâ€™s just lazy.â€
